subject: Re: [junit] JUnit-Test stops without a message on RedHat
msgSnippet: This is a stab in the dark but I experienced once that some tests that ran correctly on windows deadlocked on Solaris. The reason in that case was that the
messageBody:
This is a stab in the dark but I experienced once that some tests that
ran correctly on windows deadlocked on Solaris. The reason in that
case was that the threading models were different and those tests
tested some threading-stuff that was not correctly implemented and
when run under solaris scheduler it deadlocked.

My wife experienced that their system that was somewhat threading
intensive started behaving weirdly when they got new dual-core
machines.

There used to be a setting on the linux JVM:s (way back) where you
could set wether to use the operating systems threads or JVM-emulated
ones. I could be wrong about the details and it may not be relevant
anymore.

Since your tests just stop running without a message it could be a
similar issue you're experiencing here? I would look for
thread-related issues.


On Jan 18, 2008 11:00 AM, mcwizardxl <hri@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Since our switch to JDK 1.6 we experience strange behaviour of JUnit
> on RedHat (But not on Solaris, Suse or any of the Windows machines).
>
> The output looks as follows and should explain everything:
>
> ----
>
> Date: Fri Jan 18 02:00:05 CET 2008
> OS: Linux 2.6.18-8.el5 i386
> JVM: Sun Microsystems Inc. Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM 10.0-b19
> JUnit Version: 4.4
> Test cases:
> de.insiders.cai.JobQueueTest.testGetPut() [665]
> de.insiders.cai.JobQueueTest.testPutGet() [666]
> [... lots of testnames here ...]
> Executing 1254 test cases:
> .........................................
> [... last line repeated 28 times ...]
> ......................................
> Finished JUNIT Test on RedHat-Linux.
> TEST FAILED
>
> -----
>
> Notice that:
> 1) There is no F or E in the tests, but the test failed?
> 2) That there are LESS than 1254 dots (more like ~1230)
>
> Can anybody explain that behavior to me?
> PS: The same tests under different machines work, but the behavior
> under Redhat is consistenly wrong (but: not always after the same
> amount of tests, sometimes it even works)
>
>
